docs.snippet: The Bethesda Terrace is being restored to the vision of Calvert Vaux and Frederick Law Olmsted. They designed it as a split-level terrace overlooking the park's lake, with an underground arcade whose ceiling was composed of almost 16,000 tiles. Ov...
docs.lead_paragraph: The Bethesda Terrace is being restored to the vision of Calvert Vaux and Frederick Law Olmsted. They designed it as a split-level terrace overlooking the park's lake, with an underground arcade whose ceiling was composed of almost 16,000 tiles. Over the decades, the 50-ton ceiling weakened and its tiles deteriorated. The tiles have been in storage since being removed in the 1980s during an initial repair effort. The Central Park Conservancy renewed its plan for a $7 million restoration after getting a $3.5 million gift from the estate of Evelyn West in 2002. The arcade, originally completed in the 1860s, is expected to reopen in late January. HAEYOUN PARK AND GRAHAM ROBERTS Tile Restoration CLEANING AND REPAIRING Conservators have spent the last two years cleaning all 15,876 tiles, reattaching broken segments and repainting the tiles to match their original colors. REPLACING DAMAGE About 10 percent of the tiles were beyond repair. New ones were made in Stokeon-Trent, England, for $250 to $270 each. REINSTALLING TILE PANELS The 49 panels alternate between two patterns. Three panels, consisting only of brand new tiles, will be placed in one of the two side loggias. New Layers Of Support UPPER TERRACE A new waterproof membrane will catch water leaking through the pavement and redirect it to a subsurface drain before it reaches the ceiling tiles. STEEL SUPPORTS Brick arches have been replaced by steel beams, which, together with the existing wrought iron girders, will act as the primary support for the road above. CAST IRON RIBS The ornamental cast iron framework was painted a shade of gold with mica powder for extra sheen, accented by blue and reddish brown. Not much is known about the framework's historic colors other than that they were ''richly gilded.'' TILE PANELS Tiles on each panel are fused with mortar, then screwed into a metal frame so they can be installed into the cast iron ribs as a single unit. Each panel has 324 encaustic, or inlaid, tiles. They were made using small pieces of colored clay laid into a mold and baked together so that the colors are embedded, not just a surface glaze. Diagrams highlight the aforementioned items. (Aerial photograph by Sanborn via Google Earth; The New York Times) (Sources by Central Park Conservancy; Conservation Solutions Inc.)

headline.main: Restored Tiles In the Heart Of Central Park

docs.abstract: Chart showing process for restoration and replacement of ceramic tiles at Bethesda Terrace in New York City's Central Park; restoration includes upper and lower terraces and ceiling of loggias; $7 million project is scheduled for reopening in late January, 2007; diagram (S)

byline.original: By HAEYOUN PARK AND GRAHAM ROBERTS

docs.snippet: Their Quest: To Trump Google  In Silicon Valley, the race is on to build a better search engine than Google -- or perhaps to get bought by it. Among the contestants is Jimmy Wales, the founder of Wikipedia.   BUSINESS DAY, PAGE C1    Satellite Rad...
docs.lead_paragraph: Their Quest: To Trump Google In Silicon Valley, the race is on to build a better search engine than Google -- or perhaps to get bought by it. Among the contestants is Jimmy Wales, the founder of Wikipedia. BUSINESS DAY, PAGE C1 Satellite Radio's Next Act Last year Sirius Satellite Radio, the subscription service, got Howard Stern's show. This year it may try to merge with its rival, XM Satellite Radio. BUSINESS DAY, PAGE C1 Good Crime Year, Police Say In New York City, most crimes declined last year, though homicides rose 10 percent. Police officials herald it as a very good year. PAGE B1 Judicial Raises Sought Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. said a Congressional decision not to raise federal judges' salaries in recent years had become a ''constitutional crisis.'' PAGE A14 'Flute' Heard Round Globe A family-friendly ''Magic Flute'' was broadcast from the Met to some 100 screens. Also, a review by Anthony Tommasini. THE ARTS, PAGE E1 Jets and Giants Are In As N.F.L. Playoffs Are Set On the final day of the regular season, the Jets clinched a playoff spot with a victory against Oakland, and the Giants' berth was secured with other teams' losses. It is the fifth time both New York teams have reached the N.F.L. playoffs in a season. The Chiefs also made the cut. SPORTSMONDAY, PAGE D1

headline.main: INSIDE

docs.section_name: Front Page; New York and Region

docs.snippet: ANTIPIRACY FOILED ON HD DISCS -- An anonymous computer programmer may have skewed the competition between HD-DVD and Blu-ray, rival standards for high-definition DVD discs, by defeating a scheme that both sides use to protect digital content. [Pag...
docs.lead_paragraph: ANTIPIRACY FOILED ON HD DISCS -- An anonymous computer programmer may have skewed the competition between HD-DVD and Blu-ray, rival standards for high-definition DVD discs, by defeating a scheme that both sides use to protect digital content. [Page C1.] HOT ON GOOGLE'S HEELS -- Even as Google continues to outmaneuver its main search rivals, Yahoo and Microsoft, plenty of newcomers are trying to beat the company at its own game. Silicon Valley is filled with start-ups whose main business proposition is to be bought by Google, or for that matter by Yahoo or Microsoft. Countless other start-ups rely on Google as their primary driver of traffic or on Google's powerful advertising system as their primary source of income. [C1.] DO-IT-YOURSELF SEARCH ENGINE -- The voluntary collaborative ''wiki'' model, which was marshaled to create the behemoth online encyclopedia Wikipedia, is being recruited to build a better search engine. [C5.] STRUGGLES FOR SATELLITE RADIO -- Last year's debut of Howard Stern's radio show on Sirius Satellite Radio put the technology on the map. But stock of Sirius and its larger rival, XM Satellite Radio, have taken a battering from Wall Street, with share prices for both off about 50 percent from their year-ago levels. Now, the two companies may be considering an attempt to merge. [C1.] WHO RUNS THE MOUSE'S WEB SITE? -- Robert A. Iger, chief executive of the Walt Disney Company, is expected to unveil next week the new Disney.com Web site, which has taken more than a year to redesign. Revamping Disney.com has been a top priority as Mr. Iger seeks to extend the Disney brand by embracing new digital media. But he may be facing an equally pressing issue: Who within Disney should be running the company's Internet properties? [C1.] PUTNAM INVESTMENTS TO BE SOLD -- Marsh & McLennan Companies, the big New York insurance broker, is planning to sell its troubled mutual fund business, Putnam Investments, to a Canadian company, the Power Corporation of Canada for about $3.9 billion. [C2.] FUROR OVER A WHEAT BOARD -- Plans by the Canadian government to strip the Canadian Wheat Board of its monopoly control over most of the country's wheat and barley exports have provoked a fight that is pitting farmer against farmer and the agency against the government. [C3.] SHOPLIFTERS' MUST-HAVE LIST -- Meat and analgesics were the items most likely to be shoplifted in 2005, bumping cosmetics and health care products down to No. 3, according to a report on supermarket theft recently issued by a trade group. [C3.] READING ON THE BOUNDING MAIN -- Book It to Bermuda, a five-day literary-themed cruise out of Boston, is the latest example of a growing genre of cruises that could be called Ship Lit. Often sponsored by publishers, the cruises, aboard commercial liners, feature popular authors who give readings and seminars -- even knitting lessons -- to boatfuls of book lovers. [C4.] BEST-LAID PLANS GO AWRY -- The Wall Street Journal is introducing its new design -- and smaller size -- tomorrow. But Wall Street is shutting down for the day in official mourning for former President Gerald R. Ford, a tradition dating from the burial of Ulysses S. Grant in 1885. [C4.] DEADLY YEAR FOR NEWS MEDIA -- The year 2006 was the deadliest for journalists and media workers worldwide, with at least 155 killings and unexplained deaths, the International Federation of Journalists announced. Another group, Reporters Without Borders, using more restrictive criteria, counted 81 journalists and 32 media assistants killed, the most since the Rwandan genocide in 1994. [C4.] GIFT LAPTOPS STIR CRITICISM -- In an effort to reach out to bloggers, Microsoft recently gave away some expensive laptops loaded with a new software system. But the gifts generated more controversy than good will: many bloggers accused the company of bribery and the bloggers who received them of unethical behavior. [C4.] DIGITAL SCRAPBOOKS, FOR A FEE -- Smilebox.com, a start-up based in Redmond, Wash., is offering its customers the opportunity to build online scrapbooks with animation, music and artwork. And in a market cluttered with free services that have struggled to produce profits, Smilebox is actually attracting paying customers, according to its chief executive, Andrew Wright, above. [C6.]

headline.main: TODAY IN BUSINESS

docs.snippet: INTERNATIONAL A3-7    Hussein's Final Journey Amid a Flurry of Questions  As Saddam Hussein's body was transported by helicopter to a burial site, Iraqi and American officials discussed the intrigue, maneuvering and confusion that preceded the dec...
docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-7 Hussein's Final Journey Amid a Flurry of Questions As Saddam Hussein's body was transported by helicopter to a burial site, Iraqi and American officials discussed the intrigue, maneuvering and confusion that preceded the decision to rush Mr. Hussein to the gallows, in ways that required Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki to override constitutional, legal and religious precepts that seemed to give Mr. Hussein the prospect of a more orderly and dignified end. A1 The list of American military fatalities in Iraq has reached the milestone of 3,000 deaths since the March 2003 invasion. The number reflects how much more dangerous a soldier's job in Iraq has become in the face of a growing and increasingly sophisticated insurgency. Violence in the country is at a high, according to the Pentagon. A1 Confronted with a second, unofficial, and more graphic video account of the execution of Saddam Hussein, executives at television news organizations made a series of what one executive called ''delicate editorial decisions'' about what they would put on the air to augment the first pictures of the execution. A7 U.N. Successor's Home Delayed When Ban Ki-moon takes over as secretary general of the United Nations, he may quickly have to grapple with the crisis in Darfur, fighting in Somalia and the continuing strife in the Middle East. But he will have to wait to enjoy the secretary general's official residence in Sutton Place, which is being renovated. A5 Nuclear Debate on Iran Radio An Iranian radio program Goftegoo Radio, on a government-run station has been conducting an open debate about whether Iran should change its tough stance on its nuclear program. Its fiery discussions may be setting new boundaries for discussion about one of the most important issues in Iran. A4 Tighter Grip on Venezuela Press President Hugo Chávez of Venezuela's decision not to renew the broadcast license of RCTV, one of the country's oldest television stations and a frequent critic of his government, has fueled a fierce debate over whether he is stifling dissent in Venezuela as he strengthens his control of the broadcasting industry. A4 2 Die, Many Injured in Thailand At least six small bombs exploded around Bangkok, killing two people and wounding more than 20 in a city that remains under martial law after a coup. There was no immediate claim of responsibility. Moments later, two more bombs went off near a downtown mall, wounding eight people, including six foreigners. A3 Israeli Closer to Freedom Palestinian groups involved in holding an Israeli soldier who was captured in late June said that significant progress had been made toward the release of Cpl. Gilad Shalit, captured by Hamas and two other militant groups in a raid into Israel on June 25. A6 NATIONAL A8-16 Democrats to Propose New Ethics Rules The Democrats taking over Congress are promising sweeping changes to ethics and lobbying laws, pledging to clean up after a spate of corruption scandals under Republican rule. So far, however, their proposals are not as comprehensive as changes already adopted by many state legislatures. A1 River Restoration Effort In one of the largest river restoration efforts in the West, water is again flowing along a 62-mile stretch of the Owens River after a nearly century-long dry spell. That part of the river had been left mostly drained when upstream water, fed by snowmelt from the Sierra Nevada, was channeled 233 miles to Los Angeles. A1 Overcrowding in Madison Madison, Wis., a college town that sought to reverse the decline of its downtown in the 1980s and 90s to draw people at night and on weekends, is now facing overcrowding on the streets, vandalism and, most significantly, the police say, alcohol-related crime. Officials are now grappling with how to scale down downtown. A15 Higher Pay Sought for Judiciary Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. made judicial pay the sole topic of his second annual report, declaring that the failure by Congress to raise federal judges' salaries in recent years has become a ''constitutional crisis'' that puts the future of the federal courts in jeopardy. A14 Thousands Honor Ford Thousands of mourners filed past the coffin of former President Gerald R. Ford as he lay in state below the Capitol dome, many saying they came to pay overdue respect to an overshadowed leader. A15 Climate Scientists Speak Out Amid the shouting lately about whether global warming is a human-caused catastrophe or a hoax, some climate scientists in the usually invisible middle are speaking up. A16 Search for Stranded Travelers Small planes canvassed snow-covered roads in Colorado, searching for stranded travelers after a powerful winter storm piled drifts up to 10 feet high across much of the Plains. A16 OBITUARIES B7 Craig Hugh Smyth An art historian who drew attention to the importance of conservation and the recovery of purloined art and cultural objects, he was 91. B7 Johnny Gibson A former world-record holder in the 400-meter hurdles and successful track coach at Seton Hall University for 26 years, he was 101. B7 Dennis Linde An influential country songwriter who composed Elvis Presley's 1972 hit ''Burning Love'' and the Dixie Chicks' mordantly humorous anthem ''Goodbye Earl,'' he was 63. B7 NEW YORK/REGION B1-6 Spitzer's Term Begins As Scandals Engulf Capital Eliot Spitzer was sworn in as New York's 54th governor, after making ethics reform a central pledge of the landslide victory in his election campaign and watching in recent weeks as scandal reached the upper reaches of state government. A1 Murder Up, Other Crimes Down The New York City police commissioner, Raymond W. Kelly, called it a good year, after rapes, robberies and assaults continued to decline, and major crime over all fell by 5 percent from the previous year. B1 Snowless December a Rarity The National Weather Service said that last month appeared to be the first December without a snowflake in Central Park since Rutherford B. Hayes was president. B2 Park Project Nearly Done Calvert Vaux's original plans for Central Park called for a split-level terrace overlooking the lake. The more than 15,000 ornate tiles on the terrace's 50-ton ceiling deteriorated over the decades, but a $7 million restoration is expected to be completed soon. B1 Neediest Cases B6 BUSINESS DAY C1-6 Search for the Next Google Even as Google continues to outmaneuver its main search engine rivals, Yahoo and Microsoft, plenty of newcomers are trying to beat the company at its own game. But countless start-ups in Silicon Valley also rely on Google as their primary source of income. C1 Control of Disney Online Robert A. Iger, chief executive of the Walt Disney Company, will soon announce a new disney.com Web site. But beyond the redesign, a pressing issue faces Mr. Iger. Who within Disney should be running the company's Internet properties? C1 Struggle for Satellite Radio Last year's debut of Howard Stern's show on Sirius Satellite Radio may have put the technology on the map, but Sirius and its larger rival, XM Satellite Radio, have continued to lose hundreds of millions of dollars, and now the two services may be considering a merger. C1 DVDs Face Crack in Security An anonymous computer programmer may have skewed the competition between HD-DVD and Blu-ray, rival standards for high-definition DVD discs, by announcing on an Internet discussion forum that he has defeated a scheme that both use to protect digital content. C1 Business Digest C2 ARTS E1-22 Met Opera's Theatrical Debut A recent live broadcast, in high definition, of Mozart's ''Magic Flute'' to movie theaters across the United States was the first of six productions to be broadcast from the Metropolitan Opera through April. E1 Girding for Legal Battle In Hollywood battles, a war of words often precedes legal formalities. And so it may go if the book publisher Judith Regan proceeds with a lawsuit against the News Corporation, which owns the publishing house that fired her after the O. J. Simpson book and television project imploded. E1 EDITORIAL A22-23 Editorials: The hope of a fresh start; environmental harmony; department of household security; Verlyn Klinkenborg on edges and order. Columns: Bob Herbert, Paul Krugman. Bridge E22 Crossword E22 Metro Diary B2 TV Listings E23 Weather A17

And Wikia, a company started by a founder of Wikipedia, plans to develop a search engine that, like the popular Web-based encyclopedia, would be built by a community of programmers and users.

docs.snippet: HELP WANTED AT GOOGLE -- Desperate to hire more engineers and sales people, Google is looking for applicants with interesting backgrounds, not just high grades. [Page C1.]    ROMANIAN FARMER VS. MINING GIANT -- A small-time Romanian farmer is batt...
docs.lead_paragraph: HELP WANTED AT GOOGLE -- Desperate to hire more engineers and sales people, Google is looking for applicants with interesting backgrounds, not just high grades. [Page C1.] ROMANIAN FARMER VS. MINING GIANT -- A small-time Romanian farmer is battling an international gold giant to prevent an open-pit mine in Transylvania. With the help of movie stars and environmentally-conscious financiers, he stands a chance. [C1.] DOLLAR CONTINUES TO SLIDE -- A steady slide in the dollar since late 2005, primarily against the euro and the British pound, has steepened over the last month. Interest rates are expected to rise in Europe and fall in the United States. [C1.] AMBIVALENCE ON EURO GROWS -- Eastern newcomers to the European Union grapple over whether they want to use the Euro as their currency, and some Western members are expressing growing ambivalence as well. [C3.] LAYOFFS IN PHILADELPHIA -- The Philadelphia Inquirer is expected to lay off about 17 percent of its newsroom staff, just seven months after a group of local businessmen took over the newspaper. [C1.] A MALL GROWS IN BOEING COUNTRY -- A developer who bought 46 acres from Boeing in Renton, Wash., is convinced he has the perfect site for a shopping mall. [C6.] AMGEN TO BUY HEART DRUG OPTION -- The biotechnology giant Amgen will pay $75 million to Cytokinetics, a smaller company, for an option on an experimental drug to treat heart failure which is entering the second of three stages of clinical trials. [C3.] THE SMELL OF PROFIT IN DORMS -- A booming business in air fresheners of all kinds has grown in college dormitories. Advertising [C1.] TECHNOLOGY GIANTS IN PATENT SUIT -- An innovator who failed in a business to distribute movies over the Internet is suing technology giants like Apple, Google and Napster, claiming patent infringement. [C3.] STEEL MAKER BUYS A RIVAL -- The Nucor Corporation, the maker of steel products, said it had agreed to acquire the Harris Steel Group of Canada for $1.07 billion. [C3.] HARD ROCK CAFE SUITOR CRIES FOUL -- A rejected suitor for the Hard Rock chain of cafes and casinos claims in a lawsuit that the Seminole Tribe of Florida was the successful buyer because of improper collusion and bid-rigging. [C4.] STARBUCKS LOSES TRANS FAT -- The Starbucks Corporation is cutting trans fats from the doughnuts, muffins and other treats in half its United States stores, and plans to eventually drop trans fats from all company-operated coffeehouses. [C7.] HOME-BUILDING GIANT EXPECTS LOSS -- The Lennar Corporation, one of the nation's largest home builders, said on Tuesday that it expected a fourth-quarter loss as the company re-evaluated how much its inventory was worth in a slowing industry. [C4.] IRISH PLAN MAY BACKFIRE -- Ireland tried to cool its roaring economy by matching a portion of savings for people who locked up their funds for five years. Now that the time is drawing to a close, a huge sum is about to be released, heating up the economy again. [C9.] WORLDWIDE STOCK MARKET RALLY -- Stock markets worldwide rallied on the first trading day of 2007 on speculation that profit growth and takeovers will support global equities for a fifth year. Indexes in all 16 West European markets gained, while benchmarks in Australia, Hong Kong and Indonesia hit records. [C8.] QUALCOMM INVESTIGATED -- The South Korean antitrust agency has formed a task force to investigate the licensing and business practices of the wireless technology company Qualcomm, the latest in a string of legal battles facing the company. [C4.] BAGGAGE THEFT AT HOUSTON -- Five baggage handlers were charged with stealing luggage at George Bush Intercontinental Airport in Houston over the Christmas holiday. [A12.] ONLINE GIVING -- A new generation of billionaire businesspeople are trying to harness marketplace forces to do good works. A special report is at nytimes.com/giving. WAL-MART'S PUSH -- Wal-Mart, the discount retailer, is determined to push energy-saving light bulbs with the help of some unlikely partners. A video report can be found at nytimes.com/business. STATE OF THE ART -- A top 10 list -- not of the greatest tech products, but of the greatest individual features that surfaced in 2006. A report by David Pogue is at nytimes.com/technology.

headline.main: TODAY IN BUSINESS

docs.snippet: INTERNATIONAL A3-8    Iraq to Examine Conduct At Hussein Execution  Iraq's Shiite-led government said it had ordered an investigation into the abusive behavior at the execution of Saddam Hussein, who was subjected to a battery of taunts by officia...
docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-8 Iraq to Examine Conduct At Hussein Execution Iraq's Shiite-led government said it had ordered an investigation into the abusive behavior at the execution of Saddam Hussein, who was subjected to a battery of taunts by official Shiite witnesses and guards as he stood on the gallows. A1 Even as bloodshed widens in Iraq, some of the country's leaders are planning to build the American University of Iraq, modeled after the famous private universities in Cairo and Beirut, offering classes taught in English, teachers from around the world and graduates groomed to compete for lucrative jobs. A8 Israeli General Admits Errors The Israeli chief of staff, Lt. Gen. Dan Halutz, conceded that the military had made serious errors during last summer's war against Hezbollah in Lebanon, but said he would not resign his post. A3 Ethiopia Vows to Leave Somalia Prime Minister Meles Zenawi of Ethiopia said that his country, one of the poorest in the world, could not afford to keep troops in Somalia and that it was ill equipped to play the role of peacekeeper there. A3 Indonesian Jet's Fate Unknown Indonesian officials reversed themselves and admitted that they did not know what had happened to a passenger jet that disappeared from radar screens in bad weather on Monday shortly after issuing a distress signal. A5 NATIONAL A12-18 Ford Is Remembered For Mending the Nation Former President Gerald R. Ford was remembered at Washington National Cathedral for bringing decency, integrity and humility to mend a broken government after the pain of war and scandal. After the funeral service, his body was flown to his hometown, Grand Rapids, Mich., for a burial service today. A14 Costly Wildfires Stir Debate Wildfires burned more acres of the American landscape in 2006 than in any year since 1960, but experts say what happens in the next year or two could transform things even more through an emerging fight over the steeply rising costs of fire suppression and prevention. A12 Arrests in Luggage Thefts Officials announced the arrest of five men accused of stealing luggage from George Bush Intercontinental Airport in Houston. The arrests followed the discovery of 68 pieces of looted luggage in a Dumpster. A12 State Revisits Gay Marriage Massachusetts took a first step toward a possible ban on same-sex marriages when legislators voted to advance a constitutional amendment defining marriage as the union between a man and a woman. A12 SCIENCE/HEALTH Education Linked to Longevity The one social factor that researchers agree is consistently linked to longer lives in every country where it has been studied is education. A1 NEW YORK/REGION B1-6 Educators Struggle to Fix Troubled Middle Schools Educators across New York and the nation, driven by newly documented slumps in learning, by crime rates and by high school dropout rates, are rethinking middle school and how best to teach adolescents at a transitional juncture of self-discovery and hormonal change. A1 Rescued by a Stranger Wesley Autrey, a 50-year-old Manhattan construction worker, came to the rescue of a man who had fallen on the tracks of the No. 1 train by jumping down and lying on top of him, keeping him pressed down while the train's cars rolled overhead. A1 New Jersey's Death Penalty A legislative commission recommended that New Jersey become the first state in more than 35 years to abolish the death penalty, finding ''no compelling evidence'' that capital punishment serves a legitimate purpose, and increasing evidence that it ''is inconsistent with evolving standards of decency.'' A1 Neediest Cases B2 BUSINESS DAY C1-10 Google's Hiring Policy Google has always wanted to hire people with straight-A report cards and double 800s on their SATs. Now the company is starting to look for more well-rounded candidates, like those who have published books or started their own clubs. A1 Business Digest C2 OBITUARIES A18-19 Teddy Kollek The mayor of Jerusalem for nearly three decades, he was 95. A18 EDITORIAL A20-21 Editorials: After the Rip van Winkle years; protecting Internet democracy; a light bulb goes on; now it's Belarus's turn. Columns: Thomas L. Friedman, Maureen Dowd. Crossword E6 Weather D7 TV Listings E11

docs.lead_paragraph: As if YouTube did not have enough trouble with its users posting clips that violate copyrights, the video-sharing site, newly acquired by Google, must now find a way to remove a video depicting a Merrill Lynch banker and a supermodel in what the Associated Press calls "intimate scenes." A Brazilian judge this week ordered YouTube to filter out the video, which was the talk of Brazil when it first surfaced last fall.

docs.snippet: Google, which recently closed its $1.65 billion purchase of the video-sharing Web site YouTube, has bought a stake in China's Xunlei Network Technology, which provides file-sharing and other services. The move was widely seen as an attempt by Goog...
docs.lead_paragraph: Google, which recently closed its $1.65 billion purchase of the video-sharing Web site YouTube, has bought a stake in China's Xunlei Network Technology, which provides file-sharing and other services. The move was widely seen as an attempt by Google, which dominates the Internet search market in the United States, to compete better with Baidu.com, which controlled nearly 57 percent of China's search-engine market at the end of June, according to Analysis International, an information technology research company based in Beijing.

headline.main: Google Buys Stake in Chinese Multimedia Site

docs.abstract: Google, which recently closed its $1.65 billion purchase of the video-sharing Web site YouTube, has bought a stake in China's Xunlei Network Technology, which provides file-sharing and other services. The move was widely seen as an attempt by Google, which dominates the Internet search market in the United States, to compete better with Baidu.com, which [...]

docs.snippet: The fast-growing Chinese Web site, Xunlei.com, allows users to download music and video clips from the Internet....
docs.lead_paragraph: The fast-growing Chinese Web site, Xunlei.com, allows users to download music and video clips from the Internet.

headline.main: Google Acquires Stake in Chinese Web Site

docs.snippet: In a move to expand beyond the search business in the world’s second-largest Internet market, Google has made an investment in Xunlei NetworkTechnology, a Chinese Internet video firm, the company said. A Google spokesman said that the investment...
docs.lead_paragraph: In a move to expand beyond the search business in the world’s second-largest Internet market, Google has made an investment in Xunlei NetworkTechnology, a Chinese Internet video firm, the company said. A Google spokesman said that the investment in Xunlei would be announced today in Beijing, but he declined to give details. According to wire services, the China Daily reported that Google will team up with Ceyuan Ventures, a venture capital firm in Shangai, to buy a stake in Xunlei, which is in Shenzhen. According to the reports, Xunlei’s Web site attracts more than 50 million visitors a day and more than 80 million users have downloaded its software. The Xunlei deal would be Google’s second in as many days in China. Google is also teaming with China Mobile, that country’s largest mobile telecommunications carrier, to deliver search services to cellphones.

headline.main: China: Google Invests in Internet Firm

docs.lead_paragraph: We've made this first quiz of 2007 rather manageable, we think. All items should come immediately to mind for most casual news hounds -- or at least be easily traceable with a little sleuthing at Google. One item has a toe in the final days of 2006. The other two came post-New Year's holiday.

docs.snippet: An article last Sunday about the campuslike atmosphere at Google’s New York offices misstated the surnames of three employees. The sales-staff trainer who is considered one of the best-dressed people in the office is Jane Risien, not Risen. The ...
docs.lead_paragraph: An article last Sunday about the campuslike atmosphere at Google’s New York offices misstated the surnames of three employees. The sales-staff trainer who is considered one of the best-dressed people in the office is Jane Risien, not Risen. The sales team member who brings M&M’s for the staff is James Tipton, not Tipon. And the sales operations specialist who organized an art show for a Thank God It’s Almost Friday gathering is Laura Garnett, not Garrett.

docs.snippet: BACK DOOR FOR CORPORATE E-MAIL -- A growing number of Internet-savvy workers are forwarding their office e-mail to free, Web-accessible personal accounts offered by Google, Yahoo and other companies. Employers, who fearfully envision corporate sec...
docs.lead_paragraph: BACK DOOR FOR CORPORATE E-MAIL -- A growing number of Internet-savvy workers are forwarding their office e-mail to free, Web-accessible personal accounts offered by Google, Yahoo and other companies. Employers, who fearfully envision corporate secrets leaking through the back door of otherwise well-protected computer networks, are not pleased. [Page A1.] CALLS FOR GENERIC INSULIN -- As they examine their state health care budgets, 11 of the nation's governors are asking why there is no cheaper generic version of insulin, a drug that has been used since the 1920s. [A1.] A SECOND SUITOR FOR DELTA -- Even as US Airways increased its hostile bid for Delta Air Lines by about 20 percent to $10.3 billion, Northwest emerged as another potential suitor. Delta is said to be hoping to fend off US Airways, and has been in talks with Northwest for weeks. [C1.] G.M. TAKES AIM AT CHINA -- How General Motors will fare as Toyota passes it in market share may depend on how it performs in China, its second-largest market after the United States. [C1.] DIGITAL BILLBOARDS AHEAD -- Billboard companies are adopting digital technology that rotates advertiser images every six or eight seconds -- the better to catch the eye. [C1.] COURT TACKLES UNION FEES -- A case argued before the Supreme Court about how labor unions must handle the fees paid by nonmembers could turn out to be little more than a footnote to a long line of decisions about the respective rights of labor unions and dissident employees. [A24.] HOUSE APPROVES WAGE BILL -- The House overwhelmingly approved a $2.10 increase in the federal minimum wage in a vote that Democrats hailed as an overdue raise for low-income workers and a symbol of new leadership on Capitol Hill. [A28.] BUSH OPPOSES STEM CELL BILL -- The White House jumped back into the debate surrounding embryonic stem cell research, urging lawmakers to vote against House legislation to expand such research. [A28.] CANADIAN CABLE DEAL -- CanWest Global Communications, a Canadian broadcaster and newspaper publisher, joined Goldman Sachs to buy Alliance Atlantis Communications, owner of 13 cable channels. [C9.] APPLE SUED OVER TRADEMARK -- The computer networking giant Cisco Systems filed a trademark infringement lawsuit against Apple, claiming rights to the iPhone brand. [C13.] KODAK SELLS MEDICAL UNIT -- Eastman Kodak, as part of its struggle with the digital conversion in photography, said that it would sell its X-ray film and medical-imaging equipment operations to an investment company, Onex of Toronto, for $2.35 billion in cash. [C15.] BELARUS SIGNALS OIL DEAL -- Belarus said it had reached a compromise with Russia to end a dispute that had shut a Russian oil pipeline to Europe since Monday, but the Kremlin did not confirm any agreement. [A8.] PUSH FOR COMPETITION IN EUROPE -- European Union officials challenged governments to loosen their grip on national energy sectors, calling for a fresh wave of competition and investment in infrastructure and technology to ease dependence on powerful exporters like Russia and to combat global warming. [A5.] FINANCIER RECEIVED INFORMATION -- In recordings that the Hollywood private eye Anthony Pellicano secretly made of his own telephone conversations, a lawyer for the billionaire investor Kirk Kerkorian, left, said he told Mr. Kerkorian -- locked in a legal dispute with his ex-wife -- what the private detective was learning from what prosecutors say were his wiretaps. [C1.] CHÁVEZ AVOWS SOCIALISM -- President Hugo Chávez was sworn in to a new six-year term at a ceremony in which he defended his decision to nationalize the telecommunications and electricity sectors and promised to seek greater control over natural gas projects. [A16.] ONLINE Business Briefing Articles on these developments are at nytimes.com/business. ImClone Systems said that its Erbitux cancer drug works as a first-choice treatment for bowel cancer, sending its shares up 5.3 percent. (BLOOMBERG NEWS) Genentech's fourth-quarter profit jumped 75 percent on surging sales of Lucentis, its new treatment for the leading cause of blindness in the elderly. (REUTERS) EBay will buy the online ticket reseller StubHub to bolster its share in the market for secondary sales of seats to concerts and sporting events. (BLOOMBERG NEWS)

docs.snippet: To the Editor: If you lack time for the atomic tourism described in “Strange Love” (Jan. 5), you can use Google to see satellite photos of decommissioned B-52s at the Boneyard at Davis-Monthan Air Force Base in Tucson. Like Roman ruins...
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: If you lack time for the atomic tourism described in “Strange Love” (Jan. 5), you can use Google to see satellite photos of decommissioned B-52s at the Boneyard at Davis-Monthan Air Force Base in Tucson. Like Roman ruins, the once formidable planes are a shell of their former selves, their sawed-off fuselages lying sadly in the dust. What used to be terrifying has somehow become poignant, as if a great epoch had ended. I suppose we can find cathartic relief in the mummification of a Titan II missile, but this may be cold comfort. The United States has spent more than $5 trillion on nuclear weapons since 1940, and judging from the current administration’s Nuclear Posture Review, which was made public in 2002 and calls for a complete revitalization of the country’s nuclear infrastructure, this spending is far from done. Don’t be fooled by moth balls. Old nukes are like old rock stars — they never go away. Jeff Porter.

headline.main: Letters: Nuclear Past and Present

docs.snippet: To the Editor: If you lack time for the atomic tourism described in ''Strange Love'' (Jan. 5), you can use Google to see satellite photos of decommissioned B-52s at the Boneyard at Davis-Monthan Air Force Base in Tucson. Like Roman ruins, the once...
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: If you lack time for the atomic tourism described in ''Strange Love'' (Jan. 5), you can use Google to see satellite photos of decommissioned B-52s at the Boneyard at Davis-Monthan Air Force Base in Tucson. Like Roman ruins, the once formidable planes are a shell of their former selves, their sawed-off fuselages lying sadly in the dust. What used to be terrifying has somehow become poignant, as if a great epoch had ended. I suppose we can find cathartic relief in the mummification of a Titan II missile, but this may be cold comfort. The United States has spent more than $5 trillion on nuclear weapons since 1940, and judging from the current administration's Nuclear Posture Review, which was made public in 2002 and calls for a complete revitalization of the country's nuclear infrastructure, this spending is far from done. Don't be fooled by moth balls. Old nukes are like old rock stars -- they never go away. Jeff Porter Iowa City The writer's book, ''Oppenheimer Is Watching Me,'' is to be published this year by the University of Iowa Press.

headline.main: Nuclear Past and Present

docs.abstract: Jeff Porter letter on January 5 article about visiting Atomic Age sites

docs.snippet: Get Over Yourself  Greene Naftali  526 West 26th Street, Chelsea  Through tomorrow       There is a lot going on in the work, and the New York solo debut, of Michael Fullerton, a young Scottish artist, but unfortunately not all at once in a single...
docs.lead_paragraph: Get Over Yourself Greene Naftali 526 West 26th Street, Chelsea Through tomorrow There is a lot going on in the work, and the New York solo debut, of Michael Fullerton, a young Scottish artist, but unfortunately not all at once in a single work of art. As with so many solo shows these days, this one functions as a fragmented rebus that delves into themes that supposedly transcend art. If you follow the news release, and then go home and Google a few names, it all points rather feebly to issues concerning information, fame, power and the formulation of public identity, through both the news and the portraiture.

docs.snippet: Regulators should hold off on ruling how the New York Stock Exchange charges for its market data until questions about its new status as a for-profit group are resolved, the Securities Industry and Financial Markets association, a Wall Street lobb...
docs.lead_paragraph: Regulators should hold off on ruling how the New York Stock Exchange charges for its market data until questions about its new status as a for-profit group are resolved, the Securities Industry and Financial Markets association, a Wall Street lobbying group, has asked. The NYSE Group, which owns the exchange, is preparing to charge fees for access to ArcaBook, the real-time market data system the exchange picked up when it merged with Archipelago Holdings last year. Among the offerings the market is planning is real-time share-price data to Web sites like Google and CNBC, in return for a flat fee.

docs.snippet: The British Broadcasting Corporation said that it was in discussions with Google about putting some of the BBC’s programming on the online video site YouTube. A BBC spokeswoman confirmed the talks but said a deal had not been signed. YouTube, wh...
docs.lead_paragraph: The British Broadcasting Corporation said that it was in discussions with Google about putting some of the BBC’s programming on the online video site YouTube. A BBC spokeswoman confirmed the talks but said a deal had not been signed. YouTube, which was acquired by Google in October for $1.65 billion, has been approaching broadcasters and other owners of copyrighted material to arrange for the site to carry more authorized material.

A BBC spokeswoman confirmed the talks but said a deal had not been signed. YouTube, which was acquired by Google in October for $1.65 billion, has been approaching broadcasters and other owners of copyrighted material to arrange for the site to carry more authorized material. HEATHER TIMMONS

docs.snippet: Having been a player in one of the most dramatic stories of the dot-com boom and bust, Joe Kraus seems happy to be safely ensconced at the Internet giant Google. Mr. Kraus founded Excite, which went from a university-sponsored search engine to (as...
docs.lead_paragraph: Having been a player in one of the most dramatic stories of the dot-com boom and bust, Joe Kraus seems happy to be safely ensconced at the Internet giant Google. Mr. Kraus founded Excite, which went from a university-sponsored search engine to (as Excite@Home) one of the biggest names in the Internet business before its spectacular crash and burn at the turn of the latest century. He went on to found JotSpot, a maker of collaboration software that Google acquired in October.

docs.snippet: President Bush set broad goals last week for the adoption of alternative energy. Hoping to take on the role of filling in the details is an unlikely group: Silicon Valley's technology investors. These venture capitalists, backers of giants like Go...
docs.lead_paragraph: President Bush set broad goals last week for the adoption of alternative energy. Hoping to take on the role of filling in the details is an unlikely group: Silicon Valley's technology investors. These venture capitalists, backers of giants like Google and Genentech, have traditionally been free-market advocates, favoring ideas and innovation over government intervention. Now they are heading to Washington on a crusade to influence energy policy because they have a big stake in the outcome.

docs.snippet: NIELSEN ADDS STUDENT VIEWERS -- Ratings of shows like ''America's Next Top Model'' and ''Family Guy'' are expected to surge this week as Nielsen Media Research, a unit of the Nielsen Company, includes in its TV ratings, for the first time, the vie...
docs.lead_paragraph: NIELSEN ADDS STUDENT VIEWERS -- Ratings of shows like ''America's Next Top Model'' and ''Family Guy'' are expected to surge this week as Nielsen Media Research, a unit of the Nielsen Company, includes in its TV ratings, for the first time, the viewing of students living away from home. Advertising. [Page C1.] TECH INVESTORS GO TO WASHINGTON -- Silicon Valley's technology investors, traditionally free-market advocates, are heading to Washington on a crusade to influence energy policy. Having poured billions of dollars into alternative energy start-up companies, they have a big stake in the outcome. [C1.] HIRING IN SILICON VALLEY -- A huge increase in investment in the emerging category of clean environment technology -- from $34 million in the first quarter of 2006 to $290 million in the third quarter -- has helped spur a turnaround in job prospects in Silicon Valley. [C8.] DIGITAL DIVIDE STILL A CONCERN -- Concerns over a growing digital divide have taken a back seat to the challenge of climate change at this year's World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland. But passions still run high over what is the best way to deploy computers in the developing world. [C1.] HOW NOT TO WIN AN OSCAR -- ''Dreamgirls,'' having failed to win an Academy Award nomination for best picture despite eight other nominations and an all-out drive by its backers for top honors, may well be remembered as the picture that showed how far a studio cannot go in seeking a prize. [C1.] EARTHLINK BETS ON SECURITY -- Hoping to fortify its bottom line and attract new customers, the Internet service provider EarthLink plans to make sophisticated new computer security services available to both EarthLink users and others. ''Security is very much a moneymaker for us,'' said Craig Forman, above, an EarthLink executive. E-Commerce Report. [C7.] A SHAKY SPEECH EMBARGO -- A handshake agreement that gives the news media copies of the State of the Union address ahead of time on condition that it not be published until after the president begins his delivery has broken down. Copies of the speech could be found at sites like the Drudge Report and ThinkProgress.org well before President Bush began his address shortly after 9 p.m. last Tuesday. Link by Link: Tom Zeller Jr. [C3.] CASE LAW AND WIKIPEDIA -- The United States Court of Federal Claims rejected a decision by a court-appointed special master who cited an article in Wikipedia, the collaborate online encyclopedia, saying that the material did not meet standards of reliability. But a simple search of published court decisions finds that more than 100 judicial rulings have relied on Wikipedia, beginning in 2004, including 13 from circuit courts of appeal, one step below the Supreme Court. [C3.] GREETINGS FROM THE BILLBOARD -- Mini USA plans to start delivering custom messages to Mini Cooper owners on digital signs the company calls ''talking'' billboards that are programmed to identify approaching Mini drivers through a coded signal from a radio chip embedded in their key fob. [C3.] NEWS BLOG READERSHIP UP -- Despite some setbacks, traffic to newspaper blogs has more than tripled over the last year, according to Nielsen/NetRatings, reaching 3.8 million in December. [C3.] TELECOM LOWERS ITS FORECAST -- Deutsche Telekom, Europe's largest telephone company, cut its forecast for profit this year as because of intensified competition in Germany and the dollar's decline against the euro, which is cutting into revenue in the United States. [C2.] CAPITALIZING ON ACCESS -- The Sacramento Bee says it will introduce a new Web site focused on California government and state politics, and charge readers for it. [C6.] STOCK TABLES RETURNED -- The Washington Post and The Wall Street Journal are restoring some stock market tables that were trimmed to reduce newsprint costs. [C6.] GOOGLE-GAMING HALTED -- A favored online tactic to mock the president -- gaming the Google search engine so that the words ''miserable failure'' lead to President Bush's home page at the White House -- has been neutralized. [C6.] POSTING READERS' VOICE MAIL -- The San Francisco Chronicle has started posting some of the voice mail messages left for reporters and editors on its Web site, SFGate.com, as audio files. [C6.]

docs.snippet: INVESTING IN SMOKING -- The future of cigarettes appears to be brighter than ever. That is the message investors are sending as the Altria Group, the former Philip Morris, prepares to spin off its Kraft Foods division and become primarily a tobacc...
docs.lead_paragraph: INVESTING IN SMOKING -- The future of cigarettes appears to be brighter than ever. That is the message investors are sending as the Altria Group, the former Philip Morris, prepares to spin off its Kraft Foods division and become primarily a tobacco company. [Page A1.] MR. ICAHN COMES CALLING -- Carl C. Icahn, the billionaire financier, said that he planned to seek a seat on the board of Motorola, a move aimed at putting pressure on Motorola to use its $10.5 billion cash pile toward a huge buyback of shares. [C1.] THE WII IS THE RAGE -- Nintendo's Wii, the innovative game console, has upset the order of the video game world by taking the lead in buzz and sales over another new console, the Sony PlayStation 3. [C1.] STUMBLING START -- The dip in Sony's quarterly earnings underscores the shaky start of its long-awaited PlayStation 3 console. [C3.] A CALM INTRODUCTION -- Little hoopla visited the debut of Microsoft's latest Windows successor, Vista, reflecting how much Microsoft's influence in the computer technology marketplace has faded as the fortunes of rivals like Google and Apple have grown. [C3.] RAISING PILOTS' RETIREMENT AGE -- The Federal Aviation Administration will propose allowing airline pilots to fly until they are 65 years old, dropping a 47-year requirement that they retire at 60, said Marion C. Blakey, above, the agency's administrator. ''Experience counts; it's an added margin of safety,'' she said. [C4.] RECONSIDERING BIOFUELS -- Leaders in many countries are rethinking the billions of dollars they have spent supporting ''eco-friendly'' fuels. [C1.] A MARKETER'S SLAM DUNK -- The search for ingenious places to place advertising has discovered the support arms behind the backboards at the basketball courts of many leading college teams. Advertising: Stuart Elliott [C10.] FUEL PRICES SURGE ON FORECASTS -- Oil prices settled just below $57 a barrel -- a gain of almost $3 -- and the price of natural gas soared more than 11 percent on expectations of more arctic weather in the United States. [C11.] AIRLINES REPORT PROFIT -- US Airways and JetBlue posted quarterly profits, in contrast to losses a year ago, as they took advantage of strong travel demand and higher ticket prices. But shares of both airlines dropped as crude oil prices rose, heralding higher costs for airlines. [C4.] FROM ARMS TO ARTS -- A real estate company transforming an abandoned warehouse at a Navy shipyard in South Carolina has found unexpected demand for artistic space in the huge complex. [C9.] DOUBTS EDGE ECONOMY's OPTIMISM -- Consumers were feeling confident in January: the job market was chugging along and oil prices were down. But their optimism may dwindle on concerns that job and wage growth may slow. [C10.] SHARES END THE DAY HIGHER -- Stocks finished moderately higher in an uneven session as optimism about the economy helped investors overcome some of their apprehension about the Federal Reserve's decision on interest rates.[C11.] PUTTING UP THE BARRICADES -- The Paris city government has banned the Swedish clothing giant H&M from opening a megastore on the Champs-Élysées, the first step in its effort to stop the ''banalization'' of its famous avenue. [A1.] BUSH'S ECONOMIC OFFENSIVE -- President Bush struck back against Democratic criticism of his economic policies, in the first of back-to-back speeches promoting what the White House characterizes as 41 consecutive months of economic growth. [A14.] A MOVE TO ENSURE SAFETY -- The Food and Drug Administration announced changes to ensure that marketed drugs are as safe as advertised. [A17.] EDITOR RETURNS TO THE TIMES -- Dean Baquet, who was fired in November as the editor of The Los Angeles Times for refusing to cut jobs from his newsroom, is returning to The New York Times as chief of its Washington bureau. Philip Taubman, who has been Washington bureau chief since mid-2003, will become an investigative reporter covering national security issues. [A13.] ONLINE Business Briefing Articles on these developments are at nytimes.com/business. ALLSTATE, THE INSURANCE COMPANY, said that fourth-quarter profit rose 17 percent as calmer weather lowered claims. Net income increased to $1.21 billion, or $1.93 a share, from $1.04 billion, or $1.59, a year earlier. (BLOOMBERG NEWS) BURGER KING HOLDINGS, the fast-food restaurant chain, reported a 41 percent increase in second-quarter profit. (AP) MICHAEL J. KOPPER, a former Enron Corporation finance executive who ran illicit partnerships allowing the company to conceal debt off its balance sheets, started serving a three-year prison sentence in Big Spring, Tex. (BLOOMBERG NEWS) ELKCORP, A MAKER OF ROOFING and building products, said that it planned to accept a bid for the company from the Building Materials Corporation of America and terminate a planned sale to the private equity firm Carlyle Group. (BLOOMBERG NEWS) THE OWNER OF A HEDGE FUND management firm was sentenced to three years in prison and three years of supervised release, federal prosecutors said. Scott Sacane, who owned and controlled Durus Capital Management, pleaded guilty in December 2005 to violating the Investment Advisers Act of 1940. (AP)
